label.value: Anime: Royal Space Force: The Wings of HonnÃªamise

role.value: A Father to His Men: The chair-chucking second-in-command of the space force may be an ill-tempered hard-ass, but he firmly objects to cutting any of the pre-launch procedures, even under the threat of enemy attack.

label.value: Anime: Wings of Honneamise: Royal Space Force

role.value: A Father to His Men: The chair-chucking second-in-command of the space force may be an ill-tempered hard-ass, but he firmly objects to cutting any of the pre-launch procedures, even under the threat of enemy attack.
A Father to His Men: The reason why Jai is successful in capturing Abrush at the beginning of the movie.
A Father to His Men: Will and the older German soldier are these (respectively).
A Father to His Men: General Cypher Raige is respected and looked up to by his fellow rangers, including one who was apparently saved by him from an Ursa.
In After Earth General Cypher Raige is respected and looked up to by his fellow rangers, including one who was apparently saved by him from an Ursa.
A Father to His Men: Ivan Korshunov takes it very personally when Marshall kills Krasin. Arguably General Radek is this, too.

In Apocalypse Now, Captain Willard (Martin Sheen) alludes to Lieutenant-Colonel "I love the smell of napalm in the morning" Kilgore (Robert Duvall) as falling into this trope. Arguably he comes across as more of a Cool Uncle or Older Brother.

Gene Kranz at mission control is a model leader who commands respect. Unassuming but firm, he's cool on many levels; he's calm and collected, exactly what is required when time is at the essence, makes critical, unprecedented and right decisions on his feet and never fails to be assertive but polite. When the occasion requires it he's stingy without being smug and proudly shoots down any defeatism. His empathy solidifies him as the perfect captain.
A Father to His Men: Sgt. Nantz strives to be one. A few of his men aren't so sure, especially since there's been rumors that he purposefully got his entire team killed in Iraq.
A Father to His Men: Woodward.
A Father to His Men: Wolfstan
Wolfstan in Black Death.
A Father to His Men: General Virilus.
A Father to His Men - Hunter leads from the bottom up, contrasting with Ramsey's lead from the top style. Nevertheless, the men have a near fanatical devotion to Ramsey.
A Father to His Men: Sergeant Steiner, Lieutenant Meyer and Colonel Brandt.
A Father to His Men: 'Butcher' Cumberland looks like a spherical pig in a tricorne hat but appears to have the respect of his men, for nothing else if not his ability to keep them fed.
A Father to His Men: The Captain feels too old among his young children.
The Captain in Das Boot is very much like this, although he is only thirty years old and the men are in their late teens.

A Father to His Men: Santa Maria to his Mooks. Sometimes their dialogues would be more fitting for a group of kids on an excursion, with Santa Maria as the adult in charge, rather than a gang of bandits and their boss. This is of course due to the Rule of Funny.
A Father to His Men: Sarge.

A Father to His Men: Subverted with Hitler. Many ordinary German soldiers and civilians still look up to him as a father figure, but it turns out he has no qualms about sacrificing them all for his own selfish/crazy reasons (he thought the entire German people had "failed" him). Weidling, who surrenders after Hitler's death and tells German soldiers to lay down their weapons because Hitler has abandoned them, is a more straightforward example of this trope.

A Father to His Men: When the base falls, Ripper feels let down and remarks that the soldiers were like his children. It rings as true as anything else he says. Mandrake manages to obliquely mock him.

A Father to His Men - Although Ernest clearly isn't the father to any of the boys in camp, in his own simple-mindedness and naive innocence, he certainly feels like a father figure to them, even though they spent much of their time earlier in the movie pulling all kinds of devious stunts to make a fool of himself.
A Father to His Men: General Robert E. Lee. Colonel Chamberlain. Though not as obvious, Longstreet and Hancock also qualify, both in-movie and historically.
A Father to His Men: Col. Shaw, who was probably the first man to treat much of the 54th as equals in their entire lives.
A Father to His Men: Jackson
A Father to His Men: Spoofed: Admiral Benson is furious that the bad guy risked his men's lives in battle, because "That's my job!".
A Father to His Men: Marshall and Tiberius are this.

A Father to His Men: All three lieutenants, to some extent, but Audebert is the most obvious example. He is determined to stay alongside his men even during the most suicidal offensives, he is always polite to his subordinates, and twice he cradles a fallen soldier.
A Father to His Men : Both Captains, but Polenin moreso than Vostrikov, even if the dynamics between both captains actually make Polenin feel more like the Team Mom of the crew.
A Father to His Men: Despite Big Joe's anger, the first thing on his mind when Kelly brings in German intelligence officer Colonel Dankopf is where the best hotels and women are for his men.
A Father to His Men: Lawrence impresses the men under his command when he makes a dangerous trek back into the desert to save a straggler.
A Father to His Men: While Congress may have a cold attitude towards him, it's clear Lincoln loves and is loved by his soldiers.

Father to His Men: Lou proves to be a solid coach - demanding when needed, defending his players when it becomes known the bitch owner is screwing the team. Similarly, Gus Cantrell, though he can be harsh at times (and, in fact, for the first half of the movie, the hot hitting prospect hates how he's so hard on him), gets the best out of every one of his players.
A Father to His Men: Dennis likes to think of himself as this. The others respect that he gives it his all, but they also mostly think he's a bit of a dork.

A Father to His Men: Collins, who takes Crazy-Prepared measures to keep his men alive during Bloody Sunday and is almost tearful when he realizes that Broy has been arrested and is most likely doomed.
A Father to His Men: Admirals Nimitz, Nagumo and Yamamoto

label.value: Film: Mighty Morphin' Power Rangers: The Movie

role.value: A Father to Us All: Kimberly said this to Zordon. In an early script, Dulcea said Zordon was an inspiration. If he dies, a part of those he inspired dies with him, and the universe will suffer an "imparable blow". ...which was odd, given the ending of Power Rangers in Space. However, that was a Heroic Sacrifice.

label.value: Film: Mighty Morphin' Power Rangers: The Movie

role.value: A Father to Us All: Kimberly said this to Zordon-"Ever since you came into our lives you've been like a father to us all".

label.value: Film: Mighty Morphin' Power Rangers: The Movie

role.value:
Kimberly states this in the film version of Mighty Morphin' Power Rangers: The Movie when she tells Zordon that he has been "a father to us all" as he is dying.
 In an early script, Dulcea said Zordon was an inspiration. If he dies, a part of those he inspired dies with him, and the universe will suffer an "imparable blow".
 ...which was odd, given the ending of Power Rangers in Space.
A Father to His Men: Givi Ivanovich, Mimino's boss, when he was civilian pilot in Tbilisi.
Father To His Students: Mr. Holland becomes one of these over time as he helps all his students out. They repay the love at the end.
A Father to His Men: The officers under Chang's command hold him in the highest respect.

A Father to His Men: General Mireau puts on an elaborate show about this in the beginning when asked to attack the Anthill, but quickly changes his tune when the possibility of promotion comes up. He's a hypocrite. Colonel Dax plays it completely straight, however.
A Father to His Men: He can be gentle and understanding when the situation calls for it. Except when it comes to not grasping that "shell shock" is real.
A Father to His Men: Lt. Clemons is this, despite some of his men worrying about him being regular army.
A Father to His Men: Liu Bei makes straw footwear for his soldiers by hand. Gan Xing too, till his final moments
A Father to His Men: A rare villainous example. The Sheriff is clearly distressed when his men are hurt. He ensures they have medical attention and are properly buried.
A Father to His Men: John H. Miller, especially during the desertion scene.

label.value: Film: She Wore A Yellow Ribbon

role.value: A Father to His Men: Describes Brittles' relationship to his command.

A Father to His Men: Todd to his unit. Once he reunites with them (as they're arming the Time Bomb), they immediately stop what they're doing, salute him and fall in line behind him. For the rest of the film, they follow his orders without question.
A Father to His Men
A Father to His Men: Pike is something of a father-figure to Kirk.

In Star Trek, Captain Pike is practically young Jim Kirk's "Well Done, Son" Guy.
 And in Star Trek: The Original Series, Spock was willing to risk his life out of loyalty to Captain Pike.
 Even better - Spock ends up risking Kirk's life out of loyalty to Captain Pike. Now that's something.
 In the sequel, Big Bad John Harrison is this, as part of his motivation is to save his crew. He even calls them his family
In the sequel, Big Bad John Harrison is this, as part of his motivation is to save his crew. He even calls them his family
In Starship Troopers LT Raschyk demands the best, and gives the best (it's implied the "beer and entertainment" isn't something most platoons receive).
A Father to His Men: And to his kid, and to other people's kids.
A Father to His Men: Bache at first, and then Brian.

A Father to His Men: General Dmitri Losenko. Combined with Reasonable Authority Figure. In the novel Terminator Salvation: Cold War, he treats the men and women under his command as his family and works hard to ensure their survival, after the bombs went off. This contrasts to his commanding officer, General Hugh Ashdown; who is a hard-ass not known for being the compromising type.
A Father to His Men: Bud, to his crew
A Father to His Men: Christian—too much, as this causes him to lead the mutiny against Bligh.

label.value: Film: The Bridge on the River Kwai

role.value: A Father to His Men / An Officer and a Gentleman: Col. Nicholson. The character was based on French collaborateurs known to the author, while the actual colonel (Philip Toosey) was evidently above reproach. Even the Japanese second-in-command grew to respect him. Of course, the whole "father to his men" business is subverted when Nicholson drags sick men out of the hospital to work on the bridge.
A Father to His Men: Capt. Inouye is desperate to find Mizushima, and regrets not going on the mission to the other unit himself.

label.value: Film: The Charge Of The Light Brigade

role.value: A Father to His Men: Cardigan sees himself as this, as witness his opening monologue. To be fair, his enlisted men seem to respect him a lot more than his officers.
A Father to His Men: When Rommel arrives back in North Africa, he has a sneezing fit and when it's done, several officers offer up their handkerchiefs.
A Father to His Men: Cliff.

label.value: Film: The Hunt for Red October

role.value: In The Hunt for Red October Captain Ramius stationed many of his former officers on the Red October and they are willing to risk their lives to help him carry out his plan  to defect with the submarine to the USA. One of his officers even  takes a bullet for Ramius.

A Father to His Men: Woermann seems to be this, since he tells his men exactly what they want to hear (for example, when Oster laments that they should be Russia for the final assault on Moscow, Woermann tells him that by the time he puts n for a transfer, they'll be Masters of the World) but he doesn't really believe in the party rhetoric, is anti-Fascist, and hates the SS. He still does his job anyway.

A Father to His Men: General Bethlehem thinks he's one of these. Amusingly, it's fairly clear almost every one of his men hates him to the core but none of them want to stand up to him (assuming the other people in the army are loyal Holnists). He was just savvy enough to scare everyone into strict submission during their "conscription". We're shown that many are forcibly conscripted (including the Postman) so it's not that surprising if most aren't there by choice and hate Bethlehem. Also probably explains their poor Evil Army showing above.

In The Rock, the "being torn up about sacrifices" part leads Brigadier General Francis Hummel into the villainy. It's notable how everyone even remotely knowlegeable still talk all respect about him even after he initiates a hostage/terrorist plot. Which he intended to be just a bluff.
True to form, he is pitted against Capt. Staros.

A Father to His Men: Faulkner. While his personality is rather acerbic, many of the mercenaries join him out of old ties of friendship or loyalty; also, when he returns to England to exact revenge on Matheson he robs him to pay those who fought with him - "I can't even begin to count all the widows and orphans."

label.value: Film: Things to Do in Denver When You're Dead

role.value: A Father to His Men: It's Personal for both The Man and Jimmy; the former is because of the Relative Button, but Jimmy's only motivation is protecting his crew.
A Father to His Men: Maddie's dad.
A Father to His Men: Josh towards his staff at The Tower.
A Father to His Men: Well, Phyllis is A Mother To Her Girls and becomes a Parental Substitute to some of them while inspiring all of them to feel good about themselves.
A Father to His Men: Major West.
Major West in 28 Days Later is a dark version of this.
A Father to His Men: Hal Moore, and the North Vietnamese commander.

A Father to His Men: Pablo Chacon, despite being a drug lord, seems to actually take care of his men. The first evidence of it is seen when David picks up the drugs, and they see kids running around the courtyard. And despite One-Eye screwing up the drug mission, he doesn't suffer a You Have Failed Me moment. Pablo later even states he hates what keeps happening to his henchman whenever they run into Millers while at the carnival near the end of the film.
A Father to His Men: Captain Pritchett is interested in his subordinates' welfare. Manning... isn't.
A Father to His Men: Waverly, and one of the songs is basically about his men's admiration for him.
General Waverly in White Christmas.

Transformers: Optimus Prime. Several versions, anyway.
 In Transformers Prime, it is hinted that Breakdown is (or was) this to the Decepticon Mooks under his command

label.value: Literature: All Quiet on the Western Front

role.value: A Father to His Men: Lt. Bertinck; it helps that he was field promoted from the ranks.

A Father to His Men: Lampshaded when Duke Leto Atreides risks his life and the priceless Spice to save his men; Liet-Kynes comments that a man such as that would inspire fanatical loyalty. It's implied that this is exactly why the Emperor wants him dead, because he fears Leto will use his popularity to depose him. There are further hints that this may be a mask designed expressly for the purpose, although it's explicitly contradicted by the prequels.
A Father to His Men: Roberts. He's the one who really runs the supply ship, and he takes care of the men. Completely averted with the ship's official captain Morton.

A Father to His Men: Captain DeVriess. Under him the Caine performs admirable (if unconventionally), crew morale is high, and there's an almost brotherly bond from Captain, to Officers, to Sailors. The crew even buys him a silver wristwatch as a going away present when he's finally relieved of command. Of course, this is in direct opposite to Queeg.
A Father to His Men: Lord Suffolk. Especially for Kip.

A Father to His Men: Subverted. Mandella tries to be this but his 'deviant' sexual practises (he's hetero), and the fact that he is a stranger to their language and culture, as well as the suspicious death of a soldier who tried to assassinate him, all exacerbate the normal tension the grunts feel towards their Commanding Officer. Eventually most of his men end up getting killed because they ignore his order to evacuate a bunker. Mandella only succeeds in breaking down these barriers after he fights shoulder-to-shoulder with them against the Taurans and comes up with the plan that saves their lives (those that are left).
A Father to His Men: Miller snidely suggests that Mallory play this part when he's trying to convince Mallory to shoot Anna.
The Guns of Navarone. Miller snidely suggests that Mallory play this part when he's trying to convince Mallory to shoot The Mole.
A Father to His Men: Will and the older German soldier are these (respectively).
A Father to His Men: Potemkin.
A Father to His Men: Jackson
A Father to His Men : Both Captains, but Polenin moreso than Vostrikov, even if the dynamics between both captains actually make Polenin feel more like the Team Mom of the crew.

Used in K19: The Widowmaker: Mikhail Polenin, the first captain of the K-19. All his men love him, he takes an interest in them and is a great submarine captain... then five minutes in, he's demoted and replaced by Alexei Vostrikov, who is a drill-obsessed hardass. Not only do the men hate him because he overworks them, they feel that their "rightful" captain has been wronged.
 Almost called out by name when the Vostrikov is incredulous that the sub's crew would bring their fears directly to his predecessor.
A Father to His Men: General "I will always be right in front of you" Kuribayashi.
General Kuribayashi from Letters from Iwo Jima tries to be this, but the other officers in the army have the soldiers still be Red Shirts, and the only one this has good effect on is Shimizu.
A Father to His Men: Fletcher Christian

label.value: make a to doÂ send a pmÂ add to watchlistÂ drop watchÂ go to watchlist K19: The Widowmaker

role.value: A Father To His Men : Polenin moreso than Vostrikov
A Father to His Men: Liu Bei makes straw footwear for his soldiers by hand. Gan Xing too, till his final moments

A Father to His Men: Played with. Those trained by L.T. do see him as a father figure. He does return the feeling (having kept all of Hallam's letters to him speaking of his difficulties) but finds himself failing the "Father's Dilemma": how to tell your child "I don't know the answer".
A Father to His Men: Maddie's dad.
The Mustangs are a father and mother pair to the men of both their old unit and their current one, in the Elemental Chess Trilogy.

label.value: Manga: NausicaÃ¤ of the Valley of the Wind

role.value: A Father to His Men: Kushana to the Third Army, especially in the manga.

label.value: Series: Star Trek: The Original Series

role.value:
And in Star Trek: The Original Series, Spock was willing to risk his life out of loyalty to Captain Pike.
 Even better - Spock ends up risking Kirk's life out of loyalty to Captain Pike. Now that's something.

label.value: Series: Star Trek: The Original Series

role.value: Kirk's personal Berserk Button is anyone hurting his crew. If you hurt one of his True Companions, it's even worse.
A Father to His Men: Bilko tries to pass himself off as one of these, but is quick to drop the ruse when it is no longer useful to him.

A Father to His Men: Gru toward the minions, in a rare villainous example. He seems to genuinely care about them, and is upset when he has to lay them off.  The minions reciprocate the feeling by offering to tap into their own savings to complete the Moon launch, indicating that Gru really was an above-and-beyond employer and that the minions really care about him in return.
Boss Wolf from Kung Fu Panda 2.

The Wolf Boss, possibly a literal example since he was a wolf who refused to fire on his wolf underlings despite Shen's orders. The wolf might even be A Father to His Men in a literal sense too, given that leaders of wolf packs tend to be the daddy to the lot of them.

label.value: Western Animation: The Pirates! In an Adventure with Scientists

role.value: A Father to His Men: The Pirate Captain.
A Lady on Each Arm: Lumiere mentions this in the Cut Song "Human Again." The two mademoiselles are Mrs. Potts and Babette.

Beauty and the Beast : the special edition has the Re Cut song "Human Again" in which Lumiere sings that when the spell is broken: "I'll be cooking again / be good looking again / With a mademoiselle on each arm."

Bruce Wayne does this in Batman Begins, then does the same thing with three women in The Dark Knight. However, he only does it because Alfred told him to behave like a Rich Idiot with No Day Job, so that people don't start thinking about his activities and jump to conclusions. Alfred actually had to explain what he means, as Bruce has been out of touch for a while.
Elsewhere in the Batman franchise, Two-Face in Batman Forever has Sugar and Spice - Sugar for his healthy, 'normal' side, Spice for his twisted, acid-scarred side.

Invoked in the first Charlie's Angels movie to crash a private party; two of the Angels get in by being with Bosley, and he gets in due to this trope (and becomes worthy of the host's attention besides).
A Lady On Each Arm: Steve, when he shows up with Hannah and Julia.
In Star Trek: First Contact holodeck gangster Nicky the Nose has two flapper girls rubbing his shoulders.
A Lady on Each Arm: One patron in the illegal gambling hole is shown walking around with two women in this fashion.

label.value: Film: The Quick and the Dead

role.value: A Lady on Each Arm: Virgil Sparks (the Pride of Texas) makes his introduction this way. The Kid has his own groupies too.

label.value: Film: Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea

role.value: Ned Land is introduced this way in Disney's Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea. He briefly lets go of them to start a brawl, but quickly emerges to get them back.

In Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps, Gordon meets Bud at a fundraiser many years later. Bud has since become a billionnaire and retired and shows up with two ladies. Naturally, the ladies don't get any lines or even names, but this is partly due to Bud himself appearing only as a cameo.

A Lady on Each Arm: Henry Crawford with Maria and Julia. Later, when he visits Portsmouth, he repeats it with Fanny and her sister Susan — though in that case, Susan's presence certainly wasn't his idea.
Fairy Tail: Loke is initially portrayed this way, directly due to his former partner /master who was a Rare Female Example of this trope
Greed in Fullmetal Alchemist is introduced this way.

label.value: Series: Star Trek: The Original Series

role.value: The Star Trek: The Original Series episode "Shore Leave" ends with the revelation that all the strange occurrences have been just illusions; McCoy appears (having been seemingly killed) with a lady on each arm.

label.value: Western Animation: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs

role.value: A Lady on Each Arm: Brent's first appearance involves this.

Beauty and the Beast has Belle's father Maurice. He invents strange contraptions, gets lost in the woods on his way to a fair, ignores his horse Philippe's instincts to turn back, and ultimately ends up as the Beast's temporary prisoner.
 Speaking of Disney movies, let's not forget Professor Porter, Jane's father in Tarzan, who certainly also falls into this trope.
Absent-Minded Professor: David is one of these
Bullshot (1983). Professor Rupert Fenton, of the Royal Society of Scientific Discoverers.
Absent-Minded Professor: Mr. Myers.

Absent-Minded Professor: A genius innovator of robots, flubber, and Rube Goldberg contraptions, but don't expect him to arrive at his own wedding on time (which he missed four times), or have the common sense to sell his inventions already rather than use them for slapstick humor and to win basketball games (or at least hire someone to do it for him). It's also a remake of the Trope Namer, The Absent-Minded Professor. On the other hand, Wilson does say that he stole Phillip's ideas, so maybe he got there first.

label.value: Film: Honey, I Shrunk the Kids

role.value: Absent-Minded Professor: Wayne, of course.

label.value: Film: Honey, I Shrunk the Kids

role.value: Wayne Szalinski from Honey, I Shrunk the Kids. He is an absent-minded professor, mixed with Man Child to the point of lampshading it in Honey, We Shrunk Ourselves, and he's even more so in the TV series starring Peter Scolari.
Absent-Minded Professor: Dr. Brackish Okun, head of the alien lab at Area 51.

label.value: Film: Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade

role.value: Absent-Minded Professor: Multiple examples.

label.value: Film: Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade

role.value:
Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade.
 Dr. Marcus Brody is turned into something like this. It's frequently mentioned he got lost in his own museum (one that he was the curator for)! Granted, he was getting older... Also, while he speaks multiple languages, he doesn't appear to know any that would be helpful in the real world:
 At one point, Indy tries to return to his office and is besieged by students because he hasn't been grading any of their work. He has to climb out the window to escape.
 Subverted by Henry Jones, Sr. in the same movie: he is taken by many (including Indy) be an absent-minded professor, but in the end betrays himself as a man who is more attuned to his environment than originally thought.

Absent-Minded Professor: Hiroshi's grandfather. (The adaptations expand his role a little, and a Deleted Scene, where he shows up ready to protect Hiroshi with a lightning gun-rod and meets ZO, would've given him more of a Bunny-Ears Lawyer feel.)
Dr. Pennyworth in the spoof Monster in the Closet.
Absent-Minded Professor: Professor Cruikshank.
Absent-Minded Professor: Prof. Horatio Smith.
Professor Keenbean to an extent in the Richie Rich film.
Absent-Minded Professor: Sorenson.
Absent-Minded Professor: Daniel.
Dr. Daniel Jackson in Stargate. He sets a cup of coffee on the edge of a staircase he's walking by, leaves papers scattered everywhere, writes on whatever is nearby...
Absent-Minded Professor: Collins, the drunken mathematician on the train. It's his forgetfulness that kills Guy's alibi.
The drunk mathematician in Strangers on a Train becomes a plot point—because of his forgetfulness, Guy is suspected of a murder he didn't commit.
Absent-Minded Professor: Naturally!
The Absent-Minded Professor. Of course.

label.value: Film: The Extraordinary Adventures of AdÃ¨le Blanc-Sec

role.value: Absent-Minded Professor — even refuses rescue from the guillotine because he's too tired to leave the prison
Absent-Minded Professor: Abronsius is easily distracted by books, bats, and discoursing on how great a scholar he is.
Absent-Minded Professor
Absent-Minded Professor
Absent-Minded Professor: Margo's father, Dr. Reinhardt Lane.
Dr. Reinhardt Lane in The Shadow (1994).
Absent-Minded Professor: Paleontologist Doctor Bromley.
Absent-Minded Professor - Edmund Gwenn's character.
Harold Medford in the classic giant-mutant-ant movie Them!
Absent-Minded Professor: Cyrus.
Gregor the Elder from Waterworld, who accidentally activates his dirigible before his friends arrive, abandoning them during the sack of the atoll.
Absent-Minded Professor: Wallace. Oh, so much.
Wallace from Wallace & Gromit, though he's more "eccentric" than "scattered".
Absent-Minded Professor: Amateur paleontologist Great Uncle Matthew fits this trope. He seems to forgot about the existence of the Fossil children for years and sends no financial support.
Absent-Minded Professor: Dr. Baxter is strongly implied to be one.
Absent-Minded Professor: Prof. Horatio Smith.
Absent-Minded Professor: Dr. Baxter is strongly implied to be one.
Absent-Minded Professor: Professor Willard.
Professor Bomba from Epic, his outdated computers and messy house suggest he really doesn't get out much.

Good news everyone! Professor Farnsworth of Futurama, who is also very old.  And capable of making you read this in his voice.
 Extra credit goes to the episode "A Big Ball of Garbage", where he goes to an inventors' competition, realizes the invention he brought (the death clock) is the same one he showed last year, attempts to invent the same thing again after it's pointed out to him ("I need a new invention! Perhaps some kind of death clock..."), quickly creates a new invention (the smell-o-scope) to replace it, then only hours later... "Eureka!" "You built the smell-o-scope?" "No, I remembered that I'd already built it last year!"

label.value: Western Animation: Help! I'm a Fish

role.value: Absent-Minded Professor: MacKrill. Also counts as a Mad Scientist.

label.value: Western Animation: Help! I'm a Fish

role.value: Professor MacKrill from Help! I'm a Fish.
Pootie Tang. Even when he was a child.

Action Dad and Action Mom: In a flashback of Terry and Andy's childhood, we are treated to their parents, where the dad gives a short speech to them about the importance of family and doing what's right. Then they both pick up shotguns and leave, with audible police sirens outside and "Come on you fucking pigs!" from the mother. Also an example of Hippie Parents maybe, considering how they're dressed.
Action Dad: Steven realizes what's going on and eventually has a showdown with David.
Action Dad: Erik Heller.
Action Dad: Both Stacker Pentecost and Hercules Hansen definitely count. The latter even pilots Striker Eureka alongside his son, Chuck. And then the former does as well.
Action Dad: Rama and Prakoso.

Action Dad and Action Mom: In a flashback of Terry and Andy's childhood, we are treated to their parents, where the dad gives a short speech to them about the importance of family and doing what's right. Then they both pick up shotguns and leave, with audible police sirens outside and "Come on you fucking pigs!" from the mother. Also an example of Hippie Parents maybe, considering how they're dressed.
Action Dad: Mr. Peabody.
Action Dad: Mr. Incredible is a superhero father.
Action Hero Babysitter: Arnold Schwarzenegger as a cop going undercover in a kindergarten.
Kindergarten Cop with Arnold as a cop going undercover in a kindergarten. Hilarity Ensues.

The Cowboys with John Wayne has elements of this as his character is forced to learn how to deal with children he must use on a cattle drive ( but also somewhat subverts this trope when John Wayne's character is killed and the kids learn to kill in order to avenge his death and recover the stolen cattle).
Action Hero Babysitter: The Rock as a football player unexpectledly having to raise a ballerina daughter.
The Game Plan The Rock as a football player unexpectedly having to raise a ballerina daughter.
Action Hero Babysitter
Action Hero Babysitter: Derek Thompson

King Candy in Wreck-It Ralph may talk with a lisp, dress in frilly clothing, and use flamboyant word choices and gestures (such as calling people "silly" with a downwards wrist stroke), but he has The Chessmaster levels of cunning and is, by a long shot, the best driver in Sugar Rush until Vanellope joins the races. To a lesser extent, Rancis Fluggerbutter, also from Sugar Rush, hangs out with the Alpha Bitch and behaves like one, but he is one of the top four racers in the game and also one of its most aggressive.
Agent Peacock: Addison again.

Agent Peacock: Rupert Everett as Guy Bennett. Nobody else has ever looked this badass in extremely effeminate dark sunglasses. And when he gets attacked by jocks he simply threatens to expose their numerous earlier homosexual experiences with him. Ka-Pow!

Guy Bennett in Another Country. Nobody else has ever looked this badass in extremely effeminate dark sunglasses. And when he gets attacked by jocks he simply threatens to expose their numerous earlier homosexual experiences with him. Ka-Pow!

The Hunchback of Notre Dame: The reason why Phoebus went after Esmeralda. Clearly he was interested before, but when he saw her standing up to Frollo and kicking some ass... Yeah.
 This is highlighted when Esmeralda is nicely taking care of the guards Frollo sends after her. Phoebus ducks a metal helmet that she flings at him, Frisbee-style, looks totally love-struck, and comments "What a woman!"
Amazon Chaser: Felix, who falls for Calhoun. While Calhoun is a normal-sized woman in her own game (though a bit on the tall side), compared with Felix she might as well be Fasolt or Fafnir.

Wreck-It Ralph: Felix falls for Space Marine Sergeant Calhoun. She's rough, tough, and knows her way around a gun, in contrast to his niceness and innocence; their first meeting involves her knocking him to the ground and almost shooting him as he's admiring her. Later on, when they are both stuck in a dire situation in which she is forced to batter him repeatedly in order to escape, he smiles through each blow and compliments her strength as she's hitting him.

Amazon Chaser: The only member of his team Qualen actually admires is The Squadette, Kristel, who's notably smarter than the rest of his mooks (when making the fake distress call, she claims that one of their party is running out of insulin so the rescue team won't wait till after the storm). Subverted later in a Kick the Dog moment when Qualen shoots her dead solely to force the hand of another rebellious team member.

Amazon Chaser: Henry wants to know how "Nicole" lives with that kind of passion. He says to her, "You swim alone, climb rocks, rescue servants. Is there anything you don't do?" Later in the scene she hoists him over her shoulders to save his life.
Ever After: Prince Henry is fascinated by the way "Nicole" climbs trees, swims alone, and is strong enough to hoist him over her shoulders.
Amazon Chaser: Junior likes Becky because she's a football player.
Amazon Chaser: Isabelle's tough as nails, and the guys explicitly find her attractive for it.
Amazon Chaser: Only briefly. When Chun-Li manages to get away after finding out Guile faked his death, he says "what a woman" in response to her being called crazy.

Guy is absolutely fascinated with her. It's Zigzagged and Inverted before it's played straight though. Eep liked Guy pretty much off the bat- Grugg at one point had to save/pry Guy away from Eeps backbreaking grip-but Guy didn't return those affections at first. He spent most of the first half of the movie somewhat terrified of her and tried at least twice to get away. Doesn't help that she gets a tiny bit possessive at certain points and repeatedly manhandles him several times throughout the movie.

In The Croods, Eep is almost the same height of Guy, possibly twice his weight, impossibly fast and nimble and more than capable of kicking his ass (and does so repeatedly). Guy is absolutely fascinated with her.

Angry Black Man: Sweeney says he was an angry young man, admitting that he was Not So Different from Derek in being consumed by hatred earlier in his life.

label.value: Film: Beasts Of The Southern Wild

role.value: Angry Black Man - Wink.

Angry Black Man: Parodied by Hooper, who pretends to be an Angry Black Man to sell comics but is actually Flamboyant Gay. Also deconstructed, to some degree. It's definitely hinted that some of the rage he exhibits is real, but cloaked in irony. He also seems to be both angry at how black people are treated and, simultaneously, angry at the way the black community treats gay people. So it's complicated.

Parodied in Chasing Amy. Hooper pretends to be one of these in order to sell a comic book about a black power superhero, but he's actually a Flamboyant Gay. He's a sympathetic character, however, who laments at having to sell out.

Angry Black Woman: Wanda Sykes' character unloads on Randal when he says "porch monkey" and a host of other racial slurs openly in front of her. Meanwhile, her husband (played by comedian Earthquake) doesn't really give a damn and just wants the food. "Baby, you can't taste racism!" It's revealed in the bonus features that the majority of that scene was ad-libbed. Also a minor case of Hypocritical Humor, since before Randal insults her, she and her husband were talking about Mexican immigrants using equally offensive language.

Angry Black Man: One of the patrons in the first film who was actually quite cool and helped take action.  too bad he dies pretty early. The aerobics instructor in the sequel basically takes the exact same role, and is even played by the same actor.
Angry Black Man: Vince has a bad temper.

Angry Black Man: One could say that there are a few (particularly Buggin' Out), but the trope is somewhat inverted when one black man tells another whom is spouting ABM language that he "doesn't want to hear that horseshit." In the commentary track for the DVD release, Spike Lee specifically notes that when Buggin' Out begins ranting about the pictures in the pizzeria, that he disagrees with the character, saying that it's Sal's place, so it's his right to put whatever pictures he likes on the walls.

One could say that there are a few in Do the Right Thing (particularly Buggin Out), but the trope is somewhat inverted when one black man tells another whom is spouting ABM language that he "doesn't want to hear that horseshit." In the commentary track for the DVD release, Spike Lee specifically notes, when Buggin Out begins ranting about the pictures in the Pizzeria, that he disagrees with the character, saying that it's Sal's place, so it's his right to put whatever pictures he likes on the walls.

He excuses his own hypocrisy in exclusively dating white women by saying he's "sticking it to the white man, by sticking it to the white woman."

role.value: Subverted in Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay, as with just about every other race trope. The duo's car breaks down in a black neighborhood, and they run off when a bunch of big guys start converging on their car. It ends up they were just going to help fix the car.

label.value: Film: Harold And Kumar Go To White Castle

role.value: Subverted in Harold And Kumar Go To White Castle. Harold's cell mate is a black guy reading a book on civil disobedience who calmly reveals he was arrested because he was black. He then says that he's overweight, black, and has two gay dads, so he's pretty much immune to whatever crap people throw his way. When the police return and get him up against the wall of the cell, he calmly accepts it.

Transcended metaphorically in early episodes of Futurama which let Bender the robot speak up on behalf of the oppressed robot class. His dissatisfaction with life on Earth sometimes mirrored real life criticisms made by black nationalists, notably in the episode "Fear of a Bot Planet," the episode title itself an allusion to a seminal Public Enemy album.

label.value: Disney: The Hunchback of Notre Dame

role.value: Archnemesis Dad: Frollo takes Quasimodo in after killing his mother, but only to save his own soul and keep Quasi for later use. He raises his erstwhile son to hate himself, tells him that the world is dark and cruel, and keeps him locked away from sight to prevent being associated with him. When Frollo's atrocities increase, Quasi realizes the man's evil, calls him out on his abusive parenting, and saves Esmeralda from the murderously insane Frollo.

label.value: Disney: The Hunchback of Notre Dame

Max in Bent is willing to do unspeakably depraved things to keep the Nazis from thinking he was gay. This is somewhat justified because you really don't want the Nazis to think you're gay.

Armoured Closet Gay Banky is apparently with Hooper in Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back, though he could also possibly just be bisexual.  Interestingly enough, it also counts in this film as well. Banky throws around homophobic slurs left and right but when Holden propositions him for sex, he actually is willing at first. Hooper plays with this as well: He doesn't mind the fact that he's gay, but he doesn't let his consumers know that, especially since a gay black man is "the swishiest gay man there is".
Hooper in Chasing Amy acts as an Angry Black Man but is in real life a nice gay guy. However, he doesn't do this out of self-loathing - being an a angry radical makes him successful.

Indeed, it is probable that he turned to fundamentalist Islam because it let him fight against the society that he secretly wishes he was part of.

Armoured Closet Gay: A scandal that transpired after the film's release revealed that pastor Ted Haggard's condemnation of homosexuality apparently had quite a bit of this in the subtext. Haggard condemned the film and told his followers not to watch it, garnering a personal response from the film's directors on its official website.

Armoured Closet Gay: Begbie in the film. Robert Carlyle played him as a closeted homosexual whose bursts of rage stemmed partially from his fear of being outed, and Word of God agreed with the interpretation. When a girl he's getting frisky with turns out to be a man he amazingly doesn't attack the person in question, which at a glance seems very out of character. It's also insinuated with a scene in which Begbie makes Renton put a cigarette in his mouth, which is charged with sexual tension.

Bad Ass Beard: Alexander, and, what the heck, almost the entire Russian army. The Teutonic Knights are all clean-shaven, which is a departure from history: their rule required them to sport a Beard of Evil. This was probably for patriotic reasons, as the Russian Orthodox Church also once required its members to have beards and not shave, so it serves as an easy way to highlight difference from the Russian perspective.

role.value: Badass Baritone: Darkrai has a deep voice, too.

Badass Baritone/Guttural Growler: The Beast again — the thing is pretty odd if we consider that Robby Benson's real voice is more like a tenor (the production crew mixed Benson's lines with the growls of various wild animals). This is mentioned by Benson himself in a making-of special; his natural speaking voice is closer to the Beast's baritone, but directors have constantly asked him to pitch it higher because they think a Tenor Boy would make a better Love Interest. It's actually kind of a shock when he speaks candidly.
The indisputably badass Beast from Beauty and the Beast is a solid baritone role, as is the equally badass (though much more arrogant about it) villain Gaston.
Badass Baritone
Another one is the bouncer at the Peppermint Hippo, whose voice is insanely deep.
Badass Baritone/Guttural Growler: Karl Urban does a deep voice for Dredd that puts Christian Bale's Batman to shame (and the actor admits was hard to sustain).
Badass Baritone: Prince Alcott.
Badass Baritone: Kang.
Likewise Elba's character Marshall Pentecost in Pacific Rim. When he talks about cancellin' the Apocalypse, you believe him!
Badass Baritone: Santa.
Badass Baritone: Nikiforov is a former tenor and a very skilled soldier.
Badass Baritone: Benedict Cumberbatch's "John Harrison" delivers Badass Boasts in a deep, bass voice.
Star Trek Into Darkness: Benedict Cumberbatch's John Harrison delivers Badass Boasts in a deep, chilling bass voice.

In The Dark Knight Rises, Bane has a voice amplifier that gives him an extremely peculiar contrast between the trope (in vocal range) and jovial, eloquent word choice and mode of speech, in comparison with Tom Hardy's fairly nasal voice.

Thorin, as played by Richard Armitage, in The Hobbit. Warrior, rightful king returning, general monster-killing badass, and a baritone. He even gets to sing a song perfectly suited for his voice.
 Smaug has, by far, the deepest voice in the whole cast. And he's one hell of a dragon.
Heimdall from the film version of Thor has one, courtesy of Idris Elba. It gives him a very fitting air of gravitas.
Badass Baritone: There are no special effects involved in Kevin Grevioux's voice.

Whenever English dub Version of Goku goes Super Saiyan 3, he invokes this trope by lowering his voice an octave to show he means business. And let's not get started on the badassery that is Super Saiyan 4...
Transformers' Optimus Prime is universally this, with a voice so deep and weighty it would crush the vocalizers of lesser 'bots.

The 1937 edition of King Solomon's Mines featured Paul Robeson, professional baritone singer, as Ignosi. Ignosi is a brave warrior who returns to Kukuanaland, defeats the usurper King Twala in battle, and reclaims his throne. Since he's played by Paul Robeson, he gets to sing a couple of songs too.
Badass Baritone: Malamadre.
Badass Baritone: Don Quixote himself.
Caiaphas in the 2000 revival. Also a Badass Bass.

Badass Grandpa: Odin.
Badass Grandpa: "I am one of these braves!"
Badass Grandpa: Yoda and Count Dooku.
Badass Grandpa: Commissioner Gordon, although in subsequent films he suffers Badass Decay.

Badass Grandpa: Real Life example; Bolo Yeung was in his 40s in this movie.

Badass Grandpa: Campbell the Elder. EDWARD THE LONGSHANKS. After throwing his son's councilor/lover out a window, the enraged prince takes out a knife and attacks him. Longshanks effortlessly dodges the attack and delivers a massive pimp-slap that sends his son the floor.

Badass Grandpa / Badass Bystander: A church elder at the wedding, with no lines, gets into a test of manliness with some punks after spotting them chugging and crushing beercans. He matches them with a glass of lemonade.

Badass Grandpa: Nicola is a generation older than the heroes. He kicks just as much (if not more) ass.

label.value: Film: Captain America: The Winter Soldier

role.value: Badass Grandpa Despite Fury's age, he can kick ass, even while injured. Also, in a more literal example, Fury's grandfather was also a badass back in the day if his story is anything to go by. One of the members of the Council was an elder woman, who suddenly shows that she's completely capable to fight. And then it was subverted: it was Black Widow in disguise. Cap, himself, since he mentions that, technically, he's 95. The same goes for the Winter Soldier.
Badass Grandpa: The professional killers who retire any potential liability during the ending are well past their physical prime -probably in their late sixties- but get the job done to a T.
Badass Grandpa: Curly and Duke.

Badass Grandpa: Granddad Ray is immediately demonstrated to be one, handing out verbal smackdown after verbal smackdown on anyone who pisses him off. A very brief flashback shows his experience in the war, in which he breaches a German bunker and single handedly takes out a whole Jerry platoon with either rifle or bayonet. His first response upon seeing the zombies is to slice one’s head off with a set of pincers, and he’s the source of some wonderful swearing.
Badass Grandpa: Mudy Taylor, this grandpa catch a bullet with his BARE TEETH, nuff said indeed.
Badass Grandpa: The sheriff (an actual grandpa!) and Dolarhyde.

role.value: Badass Grandpa: The four apes returning from the previous film, Maurice and Rocket especially. This doesn't stop them from actively participating in dangerous situations, however.
Badass Grandpa: The Professor starts off drunk and looking pretty feeble. He turns out to be a war veteran and a crack archer. Also Samuel, the mute Amish toting sticks of dynamite. And a scythe.
Badass Grandpa: Honey Roy Palmer is over-the-hill, but still kicks ass in the ring.
Badass Grandpa: Pops, who used to be a boxer and scares the hell out of Mitch.
Badass Grandpa: Bernie Rose is still a scarily capable man at his advanced age.
Badass Grandpa: Milton

Badass Grandpa: The actor playing the Big Bad, Shih Kien, was sixty years old when this movie was filmed, and still portrayed a convincingly worthy adversary to the almost thirty years younger Bruce Lee.
Badass Grandpa: Chief St. Cloud.
Badass Grandpa: Both Breslin and Rottmayer.
Badass Grandpa: Bartender. Probably because he's played by the director's dad.

Badass Grandpa: More like "mentally disturbed, violent grandpa". Handicapped Badass: Screaming his head off at the opposition for so many years has made Gramps deaf and dumb (and, as a result, much harder to control when angry).
Badass Grandpa: Mr. Hennessey, played by Burgess Meredith, is such a nice old man. With moves like Bruce Lee.
Badass Grandpa: Bick at the end of the movie.
Badass Grandpa: Victor Sr.
Badass Grandpa: The Headmaster of Shaolin Temple "Wet Dream"...no, seriously. He drifts away like a ghost, teleports, and makes you bleed out of all your orifices in one strike.

Badass Grandpa: Happy learns the hard way that Bob Barker is one of these; he gets the shit beaten out of him. Counts as a Real Life Example too; Barker practiced Tang So Doo and was even taught under Chuck Norris at one point.
Bad Ass Grandpa: Wilford Brimley, believe it or not, playing Van Damme's Uncle Douvet.
Badass Grandpa Retired Badass: A former Royal Marine.
Badass Grandpa: The hobo, of course.

label.value: Film: Homeward Bound: The Incredible Journey

role.value: Badass Grandpa: Shadow's an older dog, but that won't stop him from trekking across the wilderness to get his boy back.
Badass Grandpa - George Kaplan.
Ip learned his pragmatism the hard way. It took a forced 180-split from an elderly medicine seller to teach him that improvisation was acceptable in Wing Chun.

Badass Grandpa: Shingen at age 51 is an undoubted badass, but special mention goes to Masakage Yamagata who is older than Shingen, yet still has the stones to try and talk sense into Shingen, his feudal master.

Badass Grandpa: Hunter, who thanks Danny after being rescued, because his family will have their father back. This doesn't stop him from opening a world of hurt on anyone who tries to go after Danny or Anne.

Badass Grandpa The Landlord and The Beast. Also contains a Real Life example: The Beast's actor Bruce Leung was about 55 when this movie was filmed. He did his own stunts. CGI had to assist where The Beast lifted his leg high for the earthquake stomp in the casino due to physical limitations, but otherwise it was all him. And by "limitations" we mean "he CAN perform an axe kick over his own head, but he can't HOLD his leg up there like in the shot."
Badass Grandpa: Dr. Braun is capable of kicking ass when his daughter's life is at stake.
Badass Grandpa/Cool Old Guy/Colonel Badass/Retired Badass: Col. Ludlow, after recovering from his stroke.

label.value: Film: Lock, Stock & Two Smoking Barrels

role.value: Badass Grandpa: Harry and Barry are both pretty long in the tooth, but no less badass for it.
Badass Grandpa: Machete Cortez' birthday is listed as May 16, 1944... which is Danny Trejo's birthday, making him 66.

Badass Grandpa: Lou. He pulls this Ragtag Bunch of Misfits into a badass ball team. He's a tough disciplinarian but clearly loves the colorful and crazed players he's got. He also bears a Badass Mustache.
Badass Grandpa: Don't mess with Zed, man. He will air-juggle your ass.

Badass Grandpa: Leo. "The old man's still an artist with a Thompson." Tic-Tac. Moments after Tom has hit a Giant Mook across the face with a chair, Tic Tac strides into the room and without pausing snatches the chair from Tom's hands, whereupon he and the Giant Mook inflict a No-Holds-Barred Beatdown on Tom.

Badass Grandpa: Tom Blankenship, an ex Marine sharpshooter.
Badass Grandpa: The old man at the end of the movie.
Badass Grandpa: Night guard Cecil is a badass. Justified in that the tablet also reinvigorated him.

Bad Ass Grandpa: Saul may not show it much but there is an exchange in the first film wherein he demonstrates that despite his age, make no mistake, he is a very experienced con man and he is not to be trifled with.

Badass Grandpa: Sir Walter, Marion's father-in-law, isn't afraid to swing a sword at his enemies, despite being 84 years old and nearly blind. Plus his "tumescent growth..."
Badass Grandpa / Cool Old Guy / Handicapped Badass: Kanai.
Badass Grandpa: Kirk Douglas was 63 when he filmed this movie.

Badass Grandpa: Lt. Col. Frank Slade is a tough, take no non-sense man who can still put an insensitive jerk into a Ranger choke hold, dance a tango perfectly, and will defend the integrity of others.
Badass Grandpa: Kambei is the oldest.
Badass Grandpa: Quinn.
Badass Grandpa: Kincade, an Old Retainer who takes out a number of Silva's mooks with a double-barreled shotgun.
Badass Grandpa: The movie.

Badass Grandpa: Charlie
Badass Grandpa: Lu Chan's original master, the doctor who tells him to go to Chen village, and Master Chen all count

Badass Grandpa: Well, Badass Dad if you want to get technical. It's never specified how old Bryan is, but Liam Neeson is pushing 60, and Bryan's age is mentioned to be a factor, but he can still waste a dozen villains half his age without breaking a sweat, and it's only near the very end of the movie that he starts visibly feeling the strain.
Badass Grandpa: Splinter. Badass Mustache: Sporting a truly epic Fu Manchu Badass Longrobe: Per tradition
Badass Grandpa: Heihachi. The guy is in his 70s, yet he can hold his own against Kazuya and Jin.

role.value: Badass Grandpa: The Terminator himself, both for Arnie's age and him being an obsolete model.
Badass Grandpa: Father McNally.

Badass Old People: When Carnegie tracks Eli to an elderly couple's house, they've got a cache of weapons under the couch. When Carnegie tells them to come outside with their hands up, the old lady's response is to cock her gun and curse at them.
Badass Grandpa: Il Duce. Turns out to be the Saints' daddy. Technically, he isn't a grandpa though.
Badass Grandpa: Wil Anderson, of course.

Badass Grandpa: Gordon's no slouch and this time he gets to show off his ability when he pulls his pistol and gets the drop on two mercenaries armed with submachine guns while hospitalized from a gunshot wound, no less.
Badass Grandpa: Sheriff Vaines gets a jump scare with a Crawler leaping out screaming. His reaction? Punch it in the face and knock it down.
Badass Grandpa: Field Marshal Gerd von Rundstedt. While too old to join in the July 20 plot, he has the audacity to say to Keitel over the phone "Make peace, you idiot!"

Badass Grandpa: One of the first images of the movie was a shot of Stallone's character, barechested and covered in tattoos. Nearly everyone was slack-jawed, saying, "That guy is over 60?!" The series also stars 47-year-old (in the first film) Randy Couture, then-actively competing mixed martial artist and MMA's original Badass Grandpa. Chuck Norris is 72, and looks no older than 40-50.

label.value: Film: The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey

role.value: Badass Grandpa: Balin exhibits some pretty cool sword moves during the breakout from Goblin-town.

Badass Grandpa: Since Arnold is now pushing 65 he qualifies for this. He even Lampshades it after he crashes through the front door of the local diner. Badass Grandma/Badass Bystander/Badass Adorable: The sweet and adorable little old lady who blasts a Mook who trespassed in her store/home. Even better, she has an Uberti revolver carbine conveniently within reach right in the knitting basket.
Badass Grandpa: Wilson is a father, but old enough to convincingly play this trope.

label.value: Film: The Lord of the Rings

role.value: Badass Grandpa: Speaking of Gandalf, the guy has been around since the creation of the universe. King ThÃ©oden was 71 years old when he died. In real life, Bernard Hill (the actor) was around 58 during the filming. Aragorn, being a nearly-pure Numenorean, is well into his 80s despite looking no more than half that. This is addressed in the extended edition of Two Towers, when Eowyn is flabbergasted to learn Aragorn's true age during a conversation.
Badass Grandpa
Badass Grandpa: Diego de La Vega (Anthony Hopkins) and his archenemy Don Rafael (Stuart Wilson) in The Mask of Zorro. Both of them are capable of going one on one with the much younger Alejandro.
Badass Grandpa: Lone Watie
Badass Grandpa: While Prakoso is a father, he definitely looks old enough to qualify for this trope.
Badass Grandpa: John Mason, ex-SAS man and one of the few to escape the Rock.
Badass Grandpa: Even in his sixties, in chronic pain from the cancer that's killing him, and outnumbered three to one, Books wins because he's still just that good.
Badass Grandpa: Papa Smurf, considering he’s voiced by Grandpa Smurf.
Badass Grandpa: Sword Saint
Badass Grandpa: The villainous version thereof. Fergie the Florist is in his sixties at the very least, but still has a very tight grip over The Irish Mob.
Badass Grandpa: Faulkner and Janders.
Badass Grandpa: Sir John Talbot. Singh.
Badass Grandpa: The Major has a pen-gun and isn't afraid to use it.
Badass Grandpa: Odin and Laufey are both several thousand years old and quite powerful.
Badass Grandpa
Badass Grandpa: Cohaagen puts up a surprisingly good fight against Quaid.

label.value: Film: Transformers: Dark of the Moon

role.value: Badass Grandpa: Sentinel Prime. Even after being in a coma for over one thousand years, he's still perfectly capable of taking on the whole Autobot team, without breaking a sweat.

label.value: Film: Transformers: Revenge of The Fallen

role.value: Badass Grandpa: The geriatric Jetfire still kicks major ass.
Badass Grandpa: Being dead doesn't stop Grandpa from stopping time, throwing lightning bolts, chopping goblins up with an axe or making molotov cocktails.
Badass Grandma
Badass Grandpa: Rooster must be closing on sixty by the time of the film, yet he still kicks ass with ease.

Badass Grandpa: While not technically a grandfather, William Munny is more than old enough to be one. DEFINITELY Little Bill, who's even older than Munny. Just watch him when he stares down the barrel of Munny's shotgun and calmly tells his men to kill Munny after he's dead. No matter what you think of him, the man has INCREDIBLE balls.

Badass Grandpa: Devereaux himself is pushing at least his late 60s, early to mid 70s, maybe even older then that. Despite this, because of the Unisol Augmentations and the training they underwent, He's still got the fighting performance of a mid 20 year old. Same applies to Scott, cloning aside; and to most of the older generation Unisols.
Badass Grandpa: Dr. Zeko

Badass Grandpa: Sergeant Major Plumley. Don't you dare tell him that. Best part? While the people who knew Plumley agreed Sam Eliot did an excellent job portraying him, he actually underplayed how badass the real man was.

label.value: Film: X-Men: Days of Future Past

role.value: Badass Grandpa: As a Holocaust survivor living in 2023, Magneto is, at the very least, in his late eighties/early nineties (X-Men: First Class portrayed him as being around ten in 1944).  He still lifts the X-Jet and hurls it at a horde of incoming Sentinels like it's a child's toy, takes a piece of shrapnel to the gut and slightly-less-than-casually pulls it out, and still uses the remaining wreckage to further barricade the path to Kitty and Wolverine.

label.value: Film: Yor: The Hunter from the Future

role.value: Badass Grandpa: Pak
Badass Grandpa: The old man in the movie managed to make it out the longest. If there was an opposite of a Final Girl, it would be him.

Badass Grandpa: Jean Valjean.
Badass Grandpa: Karsh.
Badass Grandpa: Mattias, full stop. Sasses Tengil's soldiers like a pro even though they could kill him for it at any moment.

Badass Grandpa: Biggles ages naturally during the course of the books. His last excursion as an over-age and deniable James Bond is a mission into the Russian Gulag in 1965, when he would have been as old as the century, to liberate old antagonist Erich von Stalhein from Soviet incarceration.

Badass Grandpa: Granddad Ray is immediately demonstrated to be one, handing out verbal smackdown after verbal smackdown on anyone who pisses him off. A very brief flashback shows his experience in the war, in which he breaches a German bunker and single handedly takes out a whole Jerry platoon with either rifle or bayonet. His first response upon seeing the zombies is to slice one’s head off with a set of pincers, and he’s the source of some wonderful swearing.
Badass Grandpa: You can tell from the picture above.
Ip learned his pragmatism the hard way. It took a forced 180-split from an elderly medicine seller to teach him that improvisation was acceptable in Wing Chun.

label.value: Justice League: Crisis on Two Earths

role.value: Badass Grandpa: Uncle Super appears to be the strongest of Superwoman's Made Men, as he takes the most effort to take down for the expanded League.

label.value: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole

role.value: Badass Grandpa: Ezylryb. Also,  Grimble, if he's as old as he seems. Right up until  Kludd's betrayal he was more than holding his own against two Pure Ones and Nyra, who can down several Guardians completely unequipped, as stated above.
Badass Grandpa - Zedd.

Badass Grandpa: While not technically Walter's grandfather, Hub can take on four guys a quarter of his age, unarmed and still beat them. Also various enemies of the Foreign Legion, the Sheik's army & the Sheik himself.

That Yellow Bastard gives us the page quote for this trope. Police Detective John Hartigan saved 11-year-old Nancy Callahan from being raped and murdered by Roark, Jr., then was framed for the rape and spent eight years in prison. After Hartigan is released, Roark gets a hold of Nancy again and tortures her. Hartigan doesn't take it well.

Badass Grandpa: L.T. Bonham
Badass Grandpa: Stegler. Never mentioned how old he is, but he's noted as being a bit of a dinosaur around the CIA offices.
Badass Grandpa: Rooster must be closing on sixty by the time of the film, yet he still kicks ass with ease.

Badass Grandpa / Badass Grandma: When Johnny was undergoing his self-imposed detoxification, his dealer, unaware that anything was going on, showed up at Johnny's house with his supply of pills. The dealer was met by Johnny's future father-in-law Ezra Carter, with a shotgun. Backing up Ezra was his wife "Mother" Maybelle. With her own shotgun.

role.value: Badass Grandpa: Arthur

role.value: Badass Grandpa: Master Yupa, a very well-known (and feared, for good reason) Old Master and Master Swordsman.
Badass Grandpa: While Robert McCall has a son who is about 20-25 years old, he doesn't seem to have any grandchildren. Regardless, he is still definitely a Badass Old Guy. Dyson as well.
Grandsanta. He's been doing Christmas runs since 1941, and (according to him) has  taken twelve shots from Axis soldiers during World War II.

Badass Grandpa / Cool Old Guy: Even with his best years behind him Ezio is still able to hold his own against men a fraction of his age. Even better than an Jun around a third of his age. To Compare, Ezio takes out 5 with relatively little effort and she struggles with two.

label.value: Western Animation: Batman: The Dark Knight Returns

role.value: Badass Grandpa: Batman, who's now in his late 50s. Commissioner Gordon, who's turning 70, and takes down a much younger Mutant who had the drop on him with a machine gun. Alfred must be in his mid-to-late 80's, yet he's still carrying on his butlering duties, and performing life-saving surgery on his boss when the need arises. Ollie Queen, AKA Green Arrow, is presumably at least the same age as Batman and is missing an arm but still kicks ass. Superman is also around the same age as Batman, despite not looking it, and is still as powerful as ever...  until he takes a nuke to the face... And less sympathetically, the Joker too.
Badass Grandpa: Max Tennyson.

role.value: Badass Grandpa: Uncle Super appears to be the strongest of Superwoman's Made Men, as he takes the most effort to take down for the expanded League.
Badass Grandpa: Anyone who can name a more whoop-ass ancient turtle than Oogway may raise their hand. Seeing how Shifu also kicks a fair amount of ass despite his age, he qualifies too.

Badass Grandpa: He's old, short and visually impaired. He still can go on adventures, perform incredible feats for a man of his age and mop the floor with whoever who tries to mess with him for real.

role.value: Badass Grandpa: Tony Stark and Bruce Banner/The Hulk have both become one.
Badass Grandpa: Vitruvius.

label.value: Western Animation: The Triplets of Belleville

role.value: Badass Grandma: Madame Souza is a tiny, club-footed old woman who is persistent enough to follow an ocean liner across the entire Atlantic in a foot-pedalled boat, at night, during a huge storm at sea, to the accompaniment of Mozart's "Mass in C Minor - Kyrie". She kicks over a car too. The eponymous Triplets are no slouches either; for elderly vaudeville performers, they have surprising proficiency with explosives.
Badass Grandpa: Carl, after a certain point in the story.
Badass Grandpa: Avatar, the protagonist, who is also something of a Deadpan Snarker.

Bald Black Leader Guy: The government agent Cobra Bubbles in Lilo & Stitch. Lampshaded near the end of the movie, when one of the aliens reminisces about a past meeting and comments, "You had hair then."
The government agent Cobra Bubbles in Lilo & Stitch. Lampshaded near the end of the movie, when one of the aliens reminisces about a past meeting and comments, "You had hair then."
Dillon in AlienÂ³. Granted, he's merely a leader of a small group of all-male convicts turned religious zealots, but still.
Avery Brooks in American History X. Yes, there's a theme going here.
Bald Black Leader Guy: Avery Brooks as Dr. Robert Sweeney, who is willing to fight for the Vinyard brothers, in whom he sees echoes of his younger self.

label.value: Film: An Officer and a Gentleman

role.value: Speaking of Louis Gosset, Jr., let's not forget An Officer and a Gentleman and the entire Iron Eagle franchise.
Bald Black Leader Guy: Delroy Lindo as Rodney Little
Bald Black Leader Guy: Sarge.
Laurence Fishburne, again, in Event Horizon, this time as the captain of a spaceship.
Bald Black Leader Guy: Roadblock, after Duke dies early in the film.
Bald Black Leader Guy: Bergin, Chief of Police. Spooner's superior and all-round ass kicker when he needs to be.
In Land of the Dead, a big, bald, black zombie leads the other zombies to march on Fiddler's Green.
Bald Black Leader Guy: Marsellus Wallace, clearly.
Bald Black Leader Guy: Abdul Elijah, leader of The Cleanheads.
Bald Black Leader Guy: One, the leader of the soldiers.
The Squad leader from Resident Evil.
Bald Black Leader Guy: Luther West seems to serve as the de facto leader of the survivors.

Bald Black Leader Guy: Subverted, and then Inverted. While Sheriff Hooper runs the police department, during most of the film, the mayor Burt Hartman is the real leader everyone listens to in the town.  That is until Hooper lets Leatherface and Heather kill him in the end. Afterwards, he makes it clear that he's now in charge by telling the two to clean up the mess before he leaves.
Bald Black Leader Guy: Paris.
Bald Black Leader Guy: Lindberg, the President of the Federated Territories, played by former professional wrestler Tom "Tiny" Lister, Jr.
Seen in The Fifth Element, where the President of the Federated Territories is both bald and black.
Bald Black Leader Guy: Morpheus.

Morpheus in The Matrix.
 Laurence Fishburne, again, in Event Horizon, this time as the captain of a spaceship.

The leader of the Grammercy Riffs, an especially powerful gang in The Warriors.
 On a smaller scale, Cleon of the eponymous gang. He doesn't last.
Bald Black Leader Guy - Leader of the soldiers.
Black Leader Guy: Augustus Gibbons is not bald but the rest fits. High-ranking NSA official, prefiguring his future role as Nick Fury.

The rebel leader in The Scorpion King. Although that film IS a ClichÃ© Storm.
Joker in AKIRA is bald, black, huge, and the leader of the motorcycle gang known as The Clowns. It's not exactly a democracy, but it still works.

Basque Grand of Fullmetal Alchemist. He's not the leader of the country, but he is a high-ranking officer (a Brigadier-General at the time of his death) and during his time as a Colonel Badass was Roy Mustang's immediate superior during the Ishvalan Civil War.
Bald Black Leader Guy: As necessitated by the events of Follow That Bird.
